signin.title: Sign in to your account
signin.2faDesc:
Open the two-factor authentication app on your device to view your authentication code and verify your identity.
You can also use your backup code.

signup.tos: I do accept <tos>Terms and Conditions</tos> and the <pp>Privacy Policy</pp>.

common.xCharsError: The password has to consist of at least {{amount}} characters.
common.passwordTooLong: The provided password is too long, maximum length is {{amount}} characters
common.tosError: You have to accept our TOS and privacy policy in order to use our services.
common.checkLeakedPasswordDesc: When enabled we check your password with the <db>{{database}}</db> database. We don't send your password to the service. First we hash your password (using SHA1) and send only the first 5 characters of that hash to the service. The service returns all leaked passwords that start with those 5 characters. At our end we check if one of these matches with your password. We show you a warning if it has been leaked before. We never store your password in plain text.

notFoundPage.title: Page not found
notFoundPage.description:
Sorry, we couldn’t find the page you’re looking for.
Please check the URL in the address bar and try again.

contact.desc:
Have something to ask?
Feel free to drop us an email at <mail>{{email}}</mail>

beta.title: Beta
beta.description: This feature is in the Beta phase. Use it with caution as there may be side effects.

checklist.desc:
Swetrix Marketplace is a platform for sharing high-quality extensions that are easy to use by anyone.
In order to ensure that extensions are free from security vulnerabilities, our team reviews all extensions before they're listed publicly.
Once you've tested your extension, make sure that it meets the entire checklist below before submitting.

list.title: The extension is secure without use of external scripts.
list.desc: Because extensions are run in Swetrix production with full access to the browser, we carefully review extensions for potential vulnerabilities. Use of external scripts is strongly discouraged and may be rejected as consequence. Make sure to remove external scripts and review your extension for potential vulnerabilities.

list.title: Code is unminified and formatted consistently.
list.desc: In order for our team to be able to conduct a security review of your extension, its source code must be submitted in an unminified and unobfuscated form. Extensions with consistent code formatting reduce the time from submission to approval. Generally, all JavaScript code styles are permitted as long as they're consistent and human readable.

list.title: Tested on multiple browsers and different websites.
list.desc: We recommend testing extensions for the last 2 versions of Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge, and IE 11. If your extension is visual, make sure that it's mobile friendly.

list.title: Extension icons and screenshots are uploaded.
list.desc:
Extension developers/designers get to submit a range of media to show off your extension.
It is required that every extension have an icon.
Finally you can add gallery images to show off your extension in action. While not required, we encourage all extensions to add these screenshots to illustrate what the extension looks like and behaves on a real example dashboard.
We recommend to add at least 1 screenshot which demonstrates the extension in action.

contents.whatAreExtensions:
Swetrix allows you to create your own extensions to extend the functionality of the platform.
These extensions work similarly to browser extensions and allow you to access and process analytics data, display customised pages and much more.

You can also publish your extensions in the Swetrix Marketplace for others to use.
contents.howDoTheyWork:
Extensions can communicate with the Swetrix platform via the Swetrix SDK.
The Swetrix SDK is a module that gives you the ability to configure different event listeners and also to transfer data from the extension to the Swetrix dashboard.
All user-installed extensions run in parallel and are isolated from each other.

The extension itself is a JavaScript file which consists of a function that takes an sdk object as an argument.

This object consists of all the APIs you can use when writing your extension.

A simple example of an extension structure:
contents.exampleLink: You can find full and in-detail explained examples in our <url>GitHub repository</url>.
contents.publish: This section of the documentation is in development..
contents.eventListeners:
Event listeners allow you to listen to the specific events from the Swetrix Dashboard and run your custom code based on it.
The method addEventListener() works by adding a function to the list of event listeners for the specified event type on which it's called.

If the function or object is already in the list of event listeners for this target, the function or object is not added a second time.

Here is a basic example of an event listener:

eventListenersList.desc: Currently, the following events are available:
eventListenersList.projectinfo: This event is triggered on load and it supplies information about the project it's running on.
eventListenersList.timeupdate: This event is triggered when user changes the time bucket, time perios or sets the date range.
eventListenersList.filtersupdate: This event is triggered when user changes the filters.
eventListenersList.load:
The event is triggered when the dashboard loads a new set of analytics data.
For example, when user opens dashboard for the first time, changes the data range or time bucket.

contents.addExportDataRow:
The addExportDataRow() function adds a new export data row into the 'Export data' dropdown.
The function takes 2 parameters: (1) the name of the row and (2) the callback which is called when the user clicks on the row.

Here is an example of how to use this function:
contents.removeExportDataRow: The removeExportDataRow() function removes an export data row from the dropdown. It takes the name of the export data row as a parameter.
contents.addPanelTab:
The addPanelTab() function allows you to add a new panel tab into the dashboard panels.

For example, Swetrix has a Country panel with 2 pre-built tabs: countries list and a map.
By using this method, you can add a custom tab with a custom HTML (or just text) content.

This function takes 3 parameters: (1) Panel ID - the ID of the panel where you want to add a new tab, (2) The content of your tab, can be either text or stringified HTML, (3) onOpen callback - a callback that is called when the user opens the tab.

supportedPanelsList.desc: Currently, Swetrix supports the following panels you can inject a tab into:

contents.removePanelTab: The removePanelTab() function allows you to remove a panel tab from the dashboard panels. It takes the ID of the panel as a parameter.
contents.test:
So, you have written your custom extension and want to test it. Cool!

At the moment, the marketplace and extensions are in beta, so for now we provide 1 way to test your extensions: to do so, you need to download and locally run the <url>Swetrix frontend repository</url>.

Once you've got it up and running, you can drop your extension into the public/assets directory, then manually add a link to your extension in the src/pages/Project/View/ViewProject.jsx file.

The result should be something like this:
contents.testInProgress:
We are currently working on draft extensions so you can upload your beta extensions to the marketplace and test them on the production version of Swetrix.
As soon as this functionality is implemented, we will update this section of the documentation.
